articles.headline: In China, Illegal Rare Earth Mines Face Crackdown
articles.snippet: Rogue mining operations produce an estimated half of the world’s supply of the most valuable rare earth minerals.
articles.abstract: Rogue mining operations produce an estimated half of the world’s supply of the most valuable rare earth minerals.
articles.lead_paragraph: BAISHAZHEN, China  The elderly rice farmer was leading three outsiders into an illegal quarry to show them the gangster-run mine that has poisoned his village’s fields and streams.

articles.headline: Utilities Seek Fresh Talent for Smart Grids
articles.snippet: The power industry is spending billions to upgrade to a smart grid from the electric grid, and is hoping to lure a younger generation of potential employees.
articles.abstract: The power industry is spending billions to upgrade to a smart grid from the electric grid, and is hoping to lure a younger generation of potential employees.
articles.lead_paragraph: GRANVILLE, Ohio  Speaking to a classroom of seventh and eighth graders at the middle school here, Lisa Magnuson shared a popular dictum from the power industry: if Alexander Graham Bell, the inventor of the telephone, could see how his technology had evolved over the last century, how would he react?

articles.headline: The Pogies: Best Tech Ideas of the Year
articles.snippet: The Sixth Annual Pogie Awards go to the best ideas in products, clever twists that make life just a little better.
articles.abstract: The Sixth Annual Pogie Awards go to the best ideas in products, clever twists that make life just a little better.
articles.lead_paragraph: Welcome to the Sixth Annual Pogie Awards!

articles.headline: Rights Groups Tie Pakistan to Militants’ Disappearances
articles.snippet: The Obama administration is alarmed by reports that thousands of political separatists and Taliban insurgents have disappeared into the hands of Pakistan’s security forces.
articles.abstract: The Obama administration is alarmed by reports that thousands of political separatists and Taliban insurgents have disappeared into the hands of Pakistan’s security forces.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON  The Obama administration is expressing alarm over reports that thousands of political separatists and captured Taliban insurgents have disappeared into the hands of Pakistan’s police and security forces, and that some may have been tortured or killed.

articles.headline: For Kodachrome Fans, Road Ends at Photo Lab in Kansas
articles.snippet: On Thursday, at a photo studio in Parsons, Kan., the last Kodachrome processing machine in the world will be shut down to be sold for scrap.
articles.abstract: On Thursday, at a photo studio in Parsons, Kan., the last Kodachrome processing machine in the world will be shut down to be sold for scrap.
articles.lead_paragraph: PARSONS, Kan.  An unlikely pilgrimage is under way to Dwayne’s Photo, a small family business that has through luck and persistence become the last processor in the world of Kodachrome, the first successful color film and still the most beloved.

articles.headline: African Unity Faces a Test in Ivory Coast
articles.snippet: Ivory Coast has become a test case of whether the global community can impose its will on leaders who refuse to recognize elections they lose.
articles.abstract: Ivory Coast has become a test case of whether the global community can impose its will on leaders who refuse to recognize elections they lose.
articles.lead_paragraph: On a continent where coups and stolen elections are far from uncommon, one thing makes the standoff over Ivory Coast exceptional: all the major powers in Africa and overseas agree that Laurent Gbagbo, the strongman leader, must go.

articles.headline: Russian Judge Extends Term for Tycoon by 6 Years
articles.snippet: The stiff prison term for Mikhail B. Khodorkovsky was seen as a signal that Prime Minister Vladimir V. Putin was not loosening control over Russia.
articles.abstract: The stiff prison term for Mikhail B. Khodorkovsky was seen as a signal that Prime Minister Vladimir V. Putin was not loosening control over Russia.
articles.lead_paragraph: MOSCOW  A judge on Thursday sentenced Mikhail B. Khodorkovsky, the Russian tycoon who was imprisoned in 2003 after defying Vladimir V. Putin, to an additional six years. It was a politically tinged decision that undermined President Dmitri A. Medvedev, who has vowed to revitalize the country’s deeply troubled legal system.
